ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Fran Moore
Frances Moore
Frances Moore
Frances Moore
Frances Moore
Frances Moore

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The class is really all about the internships at the UN. The weekly seminars are a blur - there is virtually no reading material and sometimes the professor randomly asks you to prepare a presentation on up and coming international diplomacy topics, however, it seems like there is very little rhyme or reason to this process. There is no set syllabus that is actually followed and it is sort of a fly-by-the-seat-of-the-pants process. Definitely a course for those that can tolerate disorganization, or at least close their eyes to it from time to time.

This class exposed me to issues related to climate change; it made me dig deeper to learn about them; it exposed me to international negotiations on similar matters as well as matters pertaining to development that are very crucial to me given my background and interests.
Internship.

The internships - they were what you made of them. On weeks when you wanted to focus more on your other personal/academic obligations you were definitely able to do so and I very much appreciated that.
The internship at the UN!

The opportunity to meet people I would probably have not met in my life; the exposure to prepare and present our cases to the UN Ambassadors who participated in negotiations on climate change; our contributions (i.e. facts in written form) to these Ambassadors to help them in their negotiations.
Practical experience at the UN, public speaking, and networking
meeting with ambassadors at the UN. giving presentations at the UN. what a great opportunity!
The UN internship is an invaluable experience. Presenting to UN ambassadors and conducting other tasks for UN missions throughout the semester were also great experiences.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The weekly seminars. The three hours of class time were an extreme MISSED OPPORTUNITY - there could be much more structure given to the class to lend it a more credible atmosphere. Lessons should be planned out in advance and the course should be given a natural progression. The TA was incredibly capable and this was something even she could have done to make the 3 hour seminars seem less like a damper on everyone's time.
Plan earlier on what we plan to influence and prepare early on for the presentation to the UN Ambassadors;
Foundational readings or lectures on typical diplomatic procedures or tricks.
better time.

Many readings and assignments were assigned very casually and then were never completed or followed up on. Many assignments were also given at the last minute. Better enforcement of this could be done by the TA or Professor.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: both never available.
Fantastic. Fran was such a gem.
Very good on both accounts!
The TA was on top of things and so whatever information I requested or assistance I needed I got on time and of good quality
Professor Lee has made himself more available than any other professor I have had.

The TA (Frances Moore) was the main contact person for the class and was always willing to help. She was very knowledgeable about the topics discussed in the class. Many Professor Lee also went out of his way to help the class prepare for presentations and assignments.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: A great extracurricular experience in having access to the internship.
I plan on pursuing a career in UN Diplomacy so this was great!

I am interested in development issues and this course exposed me to how such issues are being dealt with at the international level.I am interested in conservation of especially aquatic resources. This course enabled me to participate in such discussions (water, law of the sea) at the UN.The course made me dig for information in areas I would otherwise not have looked at e.g. climate change induced migration, where it is likely to occur or is occurring, and the consequences etc.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The internship, and getting to go to Copenhagen.
B/c I'm interested in UN environmental diplomacy.

It is beneficial to my career goals in the sense that I got to learn about diplomatic negotiations necessary for my country - an area that has a few transboundary rivers and potential for conflict.It connected me with people who experts in their work and also opened opportunity to make myself known in case of job opportunitiesI got to know the UN better (including its abilities and limits for making a change)

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: YES
Yes
Yes
Overall, yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes--I got to work on climate and energy policy!
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: some people always know better than you, they helped me fine tune my presentation making it concise yet powerfulDisadvantage: working in a group means it takes more time as we had to listen to all the presentations and help each other. Eventually though we all had good presentations as a result

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do not expect to work with the mission you like; be open to learn and contribute but with great respect and diplomacy; the mission has the last say; your application letter is what will place you with a mission, depending on the needs of the mission - so, be very clear about yourbackground and contribution.
